title: Chemical Files
description: Documentation requirements for chemical management including Safety Data Sheets (SDS), specimen labels, chemical inventory, and accessibility of chemical information

requirements.text: Are there current Safety Data Sheets (SDS), and copies of specimen labels for chemicals used, where the full label is not immediately accessible (e.g., rodent chemicals, product sanitizers)?
requirements.question: Are there current Safety Data Sheets (SDS), and copies of specimen labels for chemicals used, where the full label is not immediately accessible (e.g., rodent chemicals, product sanitizers)?
mandatoryStatements: Current Safety Data Sheets must be maintained for all chemicals used in the facility
Specimen labels must be available for chemicals where full labels are not immediately accessible
SDS and labels must be current and readily accessible to workers using the chemicals
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will verify current SDS are on file for all chemicals including rodenticides, product sanitizers, and other chemicals where full labels may not be immediately accessible at point of use. Specimen labels or label copies should be available to provide critical safety and use information when original containers are not present.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should maintain SDS files that are reviewed and updated when new chemicals are introduced or formulations change. Specimen labels should be kept for reference when chemicals are transferred to secondary containers or used in applications where original packaging is not accessible.

requirements.text: Are there chemical inventory logs for chemicals, including pesticides, fertilizers and cleaning and sanitizing chemicals?
requirements.question: Are there chemical inventory logs for chemicals, including pesticides, fertilizers and cleaning and sanitizing chemicals?
mandatoryStatements: Chemical inventory logs must be maintained for all pesticides, fertilizers, cleaning and sanitizing chemicals
Logs must document receipt, storage locations, usage, and disposal of chemicals
Inventory system must enable tracking of all chemicals from receipt to final use or disposal
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review chemical inventory logs to confirm they document all pesticides, fertilizers, cleaning chemicals, and sanitizing chemicals used in the operation. Logs should show quantities received, storage locations, usage records, and remaining inventory with sufficient detail to enable traceability and control.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should maintain chemical inventory logs that are updated when chemicals are received or used. Regular inventory reconciliation should be performed to verify physical inventory matches records and identify any discrepancies requiring investigation or corrective action.

requirements.text: Are there specific Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for the monitoring of anti-microbial parameters in single pass and/or recirculated/batch water systems, changing of recirculated/batch water systems (e.g., dump tanks, flumes, hydro vacuums, hydro coolers, etc.) and for monitoring pH and water temperature (if applicable)?
requirements.question: Are there specific Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for the monitoring of anti-microbial parameters in single pass and/or recirculated/batch water systems, changing of recirculated/batch water systems (e.g., dump tanks, flumes, hydro vacuums, hydro coolers, etc.) and for monitoring pH and water temperature (if applicable)?
mandatoryStatements: Written SOPs must exist for monitoring antimicrobial parameters in all water treatment systems
Procedures must specify monitoring frequencies, target levels, and corrective actions for single pass and recirculated systems
SOPs must address water change-out frequencies for recirculated/batch systems and monitoring of pH and temperature
requirements.verificationExpectations: Auditors will review SOPs for antimicrobial monitoring in water systems including single pass and recirculated/batch systems such as dump tanks, flumes, hydro vacuums, and hydro coolers. Procedures should specify target antimicrobial levels, testing frequencies, pH and temperature monitoring where applicable, water change-out frequencies, and corrective actions when parameters are out of specification.
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Operations should implement the SOPs with documentation showing antimicrobial concentrations, pH, and temperature are monitored at specified frequencies. Water change-out schedules for recirculated systems should be followed with records confirming compliance and corrective actions when monitoring reveals out-of-specification conditions.

capaInject: Implement procedures to immediately obtain missing or outdated Safety Data Sheets when gaps are identified during chemical inventory audits
Establish corrective actions for chemical storage violations including proper labeling and segregation of incompatible substances
Develop procedures for addressing out-of-specification antimicrobial concentrations in water treatment systems
Create action plans for recalibrating monitoring equipment when pH or temperature readings fall outside acceptable ranges
Implement preventive controls to ensure chemical inventory logs are maintained accurately and reviewed for unauthorized usage patterns
traceabilityInject: Maintain current Safety Data Sheets for all chemicals used in operations with version dates and accessibility records
Keep chemical inventory logs documenting receipt, usage, and disposal of all pesticides, fertilizers, cleaning and sanitizing agents
Retain specimen labels and dilution instructions for all chemicals where full labels are not immediately accessible
Document antimicrobial monitoring results including concentration levels, pH readings, water temperature, and adjustment actions taken
Archive Standard Operating Procedures for water system monitoring with revision dates and training acknowledgment records
micro_inject: Inadequate antimicrobial concentrations in product contact water allow survival and proliferation of pathogenic bacteria including Listeria and Salmonella
Recirculated water systems with insufficient antimicrobial levels create biofilm formation supporting persistent Listeria monocytogenes contamination
Failure to monitor and control pH in wash water reduces effectiveness of antimicrobial agents against E. coli O157:H7 and other pathogens
Organic material buildup in batch water systems depletes antimicrobial efficacy allowing microbial load accumulation and cross-contamination
Incorrect water temperature combined with low antimicrobial levels promotes rapid bacterial growth in flumes, dump tanks, and hydro coolers
